{{Infobox company | name = Inland Residential Properties Trust, Inc. | location = [[Oak Brook, Illinois|Oak Brook]], [[Illinois]] | foundation = 2013<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, cover page.</ref> | type = [[Real estate investment trust]] | industry = Commercial Real Estate | homepage = http://inland-investments.com/InlandResidentialTrust/ }} '''Inland Residential Properties Trust, Inc.''' (Residential Properties Trust) is a non-traded [[Real estate investment trust|Real Estate Investment Trust]] (REIT) sponsored by affiliates of Oak Brook, Illinois-based The Inland Group.<ref>http://inland-investments.com/REITs/Inland/</ref> The Trust was founded in December 2013 and started selling [[common stock]] on February 18, 2015.<ref>[http://inland-investments.com/PageLayouts/NewsDetail.aspx?id=27399] “Inland Residential Properties Trust, Inc. Initial Public Offering Declared Effective by SEC,” press release by Inland Residential Properties Trust, 2/18/15.</ref> Residential Properties Trust will invest in stabilized Class A and B [[multi-family residential|multifamily]] properties in the top 100 [[metropolitan statistical area]]s in the United States.<ref>[http://inland-investments.com/PageLayouts/NewsDetail.aspx?id=27399] “Inland Residential Properties Trust, Inc. Initial Public Offering Declared Effective by SEC,” press release by Inland Residential Properties Trust, 2/18/15.</ref>
Residential Properties Trust is a non-traded REIT,<ref>[http://www.chicagobusiness.com/realestate/20141006/CRED03/141009884/inland-plans-to-raise-1-billion-for-apartment-company]“Inland plans to raise $1 billion for apartment company,” Crain’s Chicago Business, 10/6/14.</ref> which is a company whose shares are not listed on an [[Exchange (organized market)|exchange]].<ref>http://www.investopedia.com/terms/n/non-traded-reit.asp</ref> The shares therefore have limited or no liquidity.<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pg. 6.</ref>
Residential Properties Trust will be managed by external managers<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pg. 63.</ref> who charge fees or commissions when the Trust buys,<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pg. 63.</ref> holds<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pg. 80.</ref> or sells<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pg. 85-86.</ref> real estate. External managers for Residential Properties Trust are controlled by [[Affiliate (commerce)|affiliates]] of the Inland Group<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pg. 22.</ref> and charge fees paid to Inland affiliates.<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pgs. 23-34.</ref> In this respect, the Trust’s structure shares similarities with the initial setup of its sister vehicle, [[Inland American Real Estate Investment Trust|Inland American Real Estate Trust]] (now known as InvenTrust Properties Corporation).<ref>[http://www.chainstoreage.com/article/inland-american-real-estate-trust-now-inventrust-properties-corp] “Inland American Real Estate Trust is now InvenTrust Properties Corp.,” Chain Store Age, 4/17/15.</ref> Inland American shareholders have been charged $1.4 Billion in related-party fees.<ref>[https://www.sec.gov/cgi-bin/browse-edgar?company=inland+american&owner=exclude&action=getcompany] Inland American Real Estate Trust Forms 10-K and 2014 Q2 10-Q.</ref> A March 2015 ''Wall Street Journal'' article described Inland American as a “[https://www.wsj.com/articles/latest-fear-for-property-investors-zombie-reits-1427221093 zombie REIT]” noting its failure to unwind, the plunge in value of its holdings, and the drastic cut to shareholder [[Dividend|distributions]].<ref>[https://www.wsj.com/articles/latest-fear-for-property-investors-zombie-reits-1427221093] “Property Investors’ Latest Horror: Zombie REITs,” The Wall Street Journal, 3/24/15.</ref>
All of Residential Properties Trust’s executive officers staff or direct at least one of its external managers,<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pg. 107.</ref> and they also split their time acting as directors or staff of other Inland vehicles.<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pgs. 63, 103-106.</ref> In its [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|SEC]] filings, the company disclosed that Residential Properties Trust’s officers will have [[Conflict of interest|conflicts of interest]] due to the competing demands for the time they spend between different funds, and that these might lead to them violating their [[fiduciary]] duties. The SEC filings further acknowledge that the Trust’s external managers will face conflicts of interest because of their compensation arrangements.<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pg. 63.</ref> Such actions could include purchasing assets that are not in shareholders’ best interests, or negotiating higher purchase prices for assets than they otherwise would if they were not compensated based on the purchase price, among other things.<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pg. 63.</ref>
==Fund Management== In contrast to most publicly-traded REITs, Residential Properties Trust relies completely on external managers.<ref>[http://www.inlandinvestoralert.org/wp-content/uploads/ResidentialPropertiesTrust_April2015.pdf?preview=true] "Residential Properties Trust: The latest Inland fee generator?"</ref> It has no paid staff, and is managed by five executive officers who all staff or direct one or more of the Trust’s fee-based external advisors.<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151 Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pgs. 22, 63,107]</ref> The external advisors are owned by The Inland Group,<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151 Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pgs. 22, 111, 112]</ref> and extract fees or [[commission (remuneration)|commission]]s when Residential Properties Trust buys, holds or sells real estate. Due to this setup, the fund has inherent [[conflicts of interest]].<ref>[http://www.inlandinvestoralert.org/wp-content/uploads/ResidentialPropertiesTrust_April2015.pdf?preview=true] "Residential Properties Trust: The latest Inland fee generator?"</ref>
The external advisors are tasked with running the business of the Trust, including: selecting potential real estate investments,<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pg. 7.</ref> negotiating contracts, managing properties<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pg. 17.</ref> and advising the [[board of directors]] on asset acquisitions and sales, among other things.<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pg. 114.</ref> In return, they will earn fees through schedules laid out in agreements<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pg. 63.</ref> with Residential Properties Trust. The contracts were not negotiated at [[Arm's length principle|arm’s-length]].<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pg. 63.</ref>
For example, Mitchell Sabshon is the CEO, President and a Director of Residential Property Trust. He is also the President and CEO of Residential Property Trust’s business manager<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pgs. 21, 105.</ref> and a director of the Trust’s dealer manager.<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pg. 25.</ref> The business manager receives acquisition fees,<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pg. 25.</ref> real estate sales commissions,<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pg. 32.</ref> and a host of other fees<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pgs. 23-34.</ref> for its activities. The dealer manager receives commissions and fees on every share investors buy.<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pg. 23.</ref>
Residential Properties Trust’s structure is very similar to the initial structure of Inland American.<ref>[https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1307748/000110465905042350/a05-12447_7424b3.htm#OurBusinessManager_112411] Inland American Real Estate Trust Prospectus (Form 424B3), 8/31/05, pg. 2, 3, 82-83; [http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pgs. 22, 63, 103, 105, 106.</ref> At Inland American, related-party transactions have contributed to litigation and regulatory scrutiny. These include a finding of breach of fiduciary duty by Inland American’s Special Litigation Committee,<ref>[http://www.investmentnews.com/article/20150331/FREE/150339980/sec-drops-investigation-of-inland-american-but-giant-reit-raises-new]“SEC drops investigation of Inland American but giant REIT raises new questions over fees,” Investment News, 3/31/15.</ref> a [[subpoena]] by the Illinois securities division, and problems regarding its securities renewal in California. Inland American withdrew its request for renewal of its California securities registration after regulators repeatedly raised concerns about conflicts of interest and other issues.<ref>[http://www.inlandinvestoralert.org/wp-content/uploads/July16_July29.pdf] Jan Lynn Owen (by Danielle A. Stoumbos), Commissioner, California Department of Business Oversight, July 29, 2014 letter to C. Cameron Williams (Attorney for Inland American); [http://www.inlandinvestoralert.org/wp-content/uploads/CA-Letter-for-Withdrawal-of-DRP-Application.pdf] Sun-Yeong Shin (attorney for Inland American) October 16, 2014 letter to Danielle A. Stoumbos (counsel for California Department of Business Oversight)</ref> Inland American stockholders have been charged over $1.4 Billion in fees by external managers.<ref>[https://www.sec.gov/cgi-bin/browse-edgar?company=inland+american&owner=exclude&action=getcompany] Inland American Real Estate Trust Forms 10-K and 2014 Q2 10-Q.</ref>
Since 2012, Inland American has sold hundreds of assets, resulting in over $4.6 Billion in net proceeds.<ref>[http://www.inlandinvestoralert.org/2015/01/show-us-the-money-inland-american-should-distribute-the-3-8b-earned-in-cash-from-asset-sales/] "Show us the money! Inland American should distribute the $3.8B earned in cash from asset sales"</ref> However, the Trust has so far declined to make any special distributions of those proceeds to shareholders.<ref>[https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1307748/000110465912083465/a12-28829_1ex99d1.htm] Inland American Real Estate Trust, Inc., SEC Form 8-K, 12/12/12, letter to shareholders; [https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1307748/000119312514010359/d658482dex991.htm] Inland American Real Estate Trust, Inc., SEC Form 8-K, 1/14/14, letter to shareholders; [https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1307748/000119312514099424/d671711dex99ai.htm] Inland American Real Estate Trust, Inc., SEC Form SC TO-I, filed 3/14/14, pg. 3; [https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1307748/000130774814000021/inlandamericansept30201410q.htm] Inland American Real Estate Trust, Inc., SEC Form 10-Q, 11/7/14; [https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1307748/000119312514441330/d837874dex991.htm] Inland American Real Estate Trust, Inc., SEC Form 8-K, 12/12/14, letter to shareholders.</ref> Instead, it is planning to use the proceeds to buy and develop more properties.<ref>[https://www.wsj.com/articles/latest-fear-for-property-investors-zombie-reits-1427221093] “Property Investors’ Latest Horror: Zombie REITs,” The Wall Street Journal, 3/24/15.</ref>
==Fees== The external managers of Residential Properties Trust are compensated through a set of fees charged to investors on a variety of fund transactions. Because most of the fees are not performance-based, the managers will make money on the Trust’s investments no matter how well – or poorly – they perform.<ref>[http://www.inlandinvestoralert.org/wp-content/uploads/ResidentialPropertiesTrust_April2015.pdf?preview=true "Residential Properties Trust: The latest Inland fee generator?"]</ref> Several fees are structured in a way that could incentivize external managers to act counter to the interests of investors. For example, business management fees<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pg. 27.</ref> and mortgage financing fees<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pg. 32.</ref> reward managers, respectively, for holding onto highly valued (or even overvalued) assets for long periods of time and loading up on mortgage debt.<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pg. 63.</ref>
Another fee, called an acquisition fee, is tied only to the amount of money the Trust pays for real estate.<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pgs. 25-26.</ref> Under this structure, managers do not benefit by trying to negotiate lower prices for acquisitions.<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pg. 63.</ref>
Acquisition fees have been controversial at a sister Inland product, Inland Real Estate Income Trust (Income Trust).<ref>http://www.inlandincometrust.com/</ref> Income Trust recently came under fire for its plans to purchase properties that were owned by a different Inland vehicle just months prior.<ref>[https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1528985/000089262614000243/ireit-supp16.htm] Inland Real Estate Income Trust, Supplement 16 dated 9/16/2014 to the Prospectus dated 4/16/14, p.2.</ref> The ''Wall Street Journal'' dubbed the transaction a “[https://www.wsj.com/articles/plots-ploys-1410904252 boomerang buy]”. As the ''Journal'' reported, “Inland Real Estate Income Trust Inc. said it will pay $318 million for 15 shopping centers owned until earlier this year by one of its sister REITs.”<ref>[https://www.wsj.com/articles/plots-ploys-1410904252] “Plots & Ploys: Boomerang Buy,” The Wall Street Journal, 9/17/14.</ref> Income Trust planned to charge shareholders a $5 million acquisition fee.<ref>[https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1528985/000089262614000243/ireit-supp16.htm] Inland Real Estate Income Trust, Supplement 16 dated 9/16/2014 to the Prospectus dated 4/16/14, p.2.</ref> The proposed acquisition fee was on top of the portfolio’s $318 million<ref>[https://www.wsj.com/articles/plots-ploys-1410904252] “Plots & Ploys: Boomerang Buy,” The Wall Street Journal, 9/17/14.</ref> price tag and closing costs.<ref>[https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1528985/000089262614000243/ireit-supp16.htm] Inland Real Estate Income Trust, Supplement 16 dated 9/16/2014 to the Prospectus dated 4/16/14.</ref> Income Trust admitted that it did not obtain independent appraisals of the properties in the portfolio.<ref>[https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1528985/000089262614000243/ireit-supp16.htm] Inland Real Estate Income Trust, Supplement 16 dated 9/16/2014 to the Prospectus dated 4/16/14.</ref> On November 5, 2014, Income Trust announced that it agreed to permanently waive the acquisition fee.<ref>[https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1528985/000089262614000269/ireit-supp19.htm] Inland Real Estate Income Trust, Inc., Supplement 19 dated 11/5/14 to the Prospectus dated 4/16/14; [http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20140919005058/en/Inland-Real-Estate-Income-Trust%E2%80%99s-insider-fees#.VByWJhZq0gk] “Inland Real Estate Income Trust’s insider fees for boomerang acquisition questioned by UNITE HERE,” press release by UNITE HERE, 9/19/14; [https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1528985/000089262614000243/ireit-supp16.htm] Inland Real Estate Income Trust, Inc., Supplement 16 dated 9/16/14 to the Prospectus dated 4/16/14, pg. 2; [http://www.inlandinvestoralert.org/2014/11/inland-real-estate-income-trust-backpedals-on-hefty-acquisition-fee-could-go-further-says-unite-here/] “Inland Real Estate Income Trust backpedals on hefty acquisition fee, could go further,” press release by UNITE HERE, 11/7/14.</ref>
==Competition for Deals== Residential Properties Trust’s executive officers all staff or direct one or more other Inland investment vehicles<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pgs. 103-106.</ref> that could compete with the new Trust for deals. They could also face a conflict of interest should one Inland vehicle attempt offload assets to another,<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pgs. 21-22.</ref> like the “boomerang buy” that Income Trust engaged in, as mentioned above.
Mitchell Sabshon, for instance, is the CEO, President and a Director of Residential Properties Trust. He is also CEO and Director of Income Trust and a director<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pg. 105.</ref> of Inland Private Capital Corp.<ref>http://inland-investments.com/privateplacements/</ref> Both of these vehicles invest in multifamily products.<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, pgs. 4, 20-21, 99.</ref>
==Apartment REIT Sector== Residential Properties Trust is targeting multifamily properties.<ref>[http://www.snl.com/IRWebLinkX/file.aspx?iid=4562566&fid=1001195151] Inland Residential Properties Trust, Prospectus dated 2/17/15, cover page.</ref> In February 2015, a [[mutual fund]] manager was quoted in the ''Wall Street Journal'' as saying, “You’ve got more supply coming into the market than people were hoping, and we’ve had earnings reports that on the whole I’m not thrilled with.” The article noted slower growth and talk of oversupply in the apartment sector.<ref>[https://www.wsj.com/articles/after-boom-bust-could-be-upon-apartment-reits-1424197856] “After Boom, Bust Could Be Upon Apartment REITs” The Wall Street Journal, 2/17/15.</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=May 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = John Bredenkamp | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = John Arnold Bredenkamp | birth_date = {{bda|1940|08|11|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Kimberley, Northern Cape|Kimberley]], South Africa | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = Zimbabwean, South African and Dutch | religion = | ethnicity = | residence = | education = [[Prince Edward School]] | alma mater = | occupation = | known for = founder, [[Casalee Group]] | boards = | salary = | networth = £700 million<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/news/2016/apr/06/mugabe-zimbabwe-john-bredenkamp-billy-rautenbach-offshore-sanctions-panama-papers</ref> | spouse = | parents = | children = | relations = | website = }} '''John Arnold Bredenkamp''' (born 11 August 1940) is a Zimbabwean businessman and former rugby player. He is the founder of the [[Casalee Group]].
==Early life== Born in [[Kimberley, Northern Cape|Kimberley]], South Africa, Bredenkamp moved with his family to [[Southern Rhodesia]] while he was still a child. He was orphaned in his mid-teens on his birthday when while he was riding his bike, on return he found his father had shot his mother and sister and then shot himself. His sister survived the shooting. He was educated in Southern Rhodesia at [[Prince Edward School]], [[Harare|Salisbury]]. Of Dutch ancestry, Bredenkamp registered as a Rhodesian citizen in 1958. He is reported to have lost Zimbabwean citizenship "by default" in 1984, but this was restored to him shortly thereafter.
Bredenkamp is reported to hold Zimbabwean, South African and Dutch passports. The matter of his nationality was a matter of dispute with some Zimbabwean officials towards the end of 2006.
As a Rugby Union international, he captained Rhodesia from 1965 to 1968.
==Early career== After his graduation, Bredenkamp joined [[Gallaher Limited]], an international tobacco company in Zimbabwe (then Rhodesia), as a leaf buyer. In 1968 he was transferred to Niemeyer in the Netherlands, where he rose to the position of leaf director.
After leaving Gallaher in 1976 Bredenkamp founded the Casalee Group of companies registered in [[Antwerp, Belgium]]. It is believed that the Casalee operation was involved in the sale of Rhodesian tobacco on world markets, through evasion of UN sanctions. Casalee was primarily a leaf tobacco merchanting company but was also engaged in general trading and an active initiator of counter trade and barter deals. The Casalee Group grew over 16 years to become the fifth largest tobacco merchant in the world and the biggest non-US leaf tobacco company. The Group employed 2,500 people and had offices in all the major tobacco growing countries in the world including the USA (Winston-Salem), Argentina, Brazil, Bulgaria, China, Greece, India, Indonesia, Italy, Portugal, Russia, Spain, Thailand, Turkey and [[Yugoslavia]]. The company owned tobacco-processing factories in the Netherlands, Zimbabwe, Malawi and Brazil.
The Casalee Group of companies was sold in 1993 to Universal Leaf Tobacco, the largest leaf tobacco company in the world. Since then, Bredenkamp has expanded his business interests into many other different areas, mainly through the Zimbabwe registered Breco company.<ref>The Guardian, 9 June 2006: [https://www.theguardian.com/zimbabwe/article/0,,1793719,00.html Tycoon flees Zimbabwe in private jet]</ref>
==Role in Zimbabwe== Bredenkamp's career took off in earnest during the late 1970s when he became deeply involved in the commercial affairs of the embargoed [[Unilateral Declaration of Independence (Rhodesia)|UDI]] regime in Rhodesia. It has been claimed that he effectively ran the finances of the Rhodesian armed forces during the later stages of the [[Rhodesia|Bush War]].<ref>newzimbabwe.com :[http://www.newzimbabwe.com/pages/quit12.14272.html financial and political dealings of Bredenkamp] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120206015906/http://www.newzimbabwe.com/pages/quit12.14272.html |date= 6 February 2012 }}</ref> In this capacity, he brokered export sales of Rhodesian products (mainly tobacco) and used the proceeds to fund the purchase of munitions and military equipment. His "sanctions busting" deals (often involving complex barter transactions) sustained the UDI regime for far longer than would otherwise have been possible. These deals were entirely legal under Rhodesian law.
After independence in 1980, Bredenkamp left Zimbabwe and moved his base of operations to Belgium. However, he remained involved in commodity trading and defence procurement. He made himself useful in certain quarters. In 1984 he made his peace with the rulers of the new Zimbabwe and was able to return home. Zimbabwe provided a hospitable base for Bredenkamp's dealings with customers in Africa and the Middle East. These dealings made Bredenkamp and his associates very wealthy men. They also helped sustain the Zimbabwean economy in a time of some turbulence.
Bredenkamp gained considerable clout in the political and economic affairs of Zimbabwe. It is known that he played a significant role in the events surrounding Zimbabwe's intervention in the [[Democratic Republic of Congo|DRC]] between 1998 and 2003. This intervention involved using the Zimbabwean army and air force to support the [[Laurent Kabila|Kabila]] government in its war with rebels backed by Uganda and Rwanda. There appears to have been some linkage between the intervention and generous mining concessions granted by the DRC to figures in the Zimbabwe political and business elite.<ref>UN report :[http://www.afrol.com/Countries/DRC/documents/un_resources_2002_govt_zim.htm – Zimbabwe involvement in DRC minerals] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071215131737/http://www.afrol.com/Countries/DRC/documents/un_resources_2002_govt_zim.htm |date=15 December 2007 }}</ref> When Zimbabwe was subject to EU sanctions from 1999 onwards, the Mugabe regime was able to call on sanctions busting expertise from the UDI era to keep its armed forces supplied.<ref>House of Commons, 18 November 2002 :[https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200203/cmhansrd/vo021118/text/21118w02.htm debate on Zimbabwe]</ref>
Bredenkamp became something of a power behind the scenes in the ruling ZANU-PF party. It is claimed that he sought to facilitate the early retirement of [[Robert Mugabe|President Mugabe]] in 2004 and his replacement by [[Emmerson Mnangagwa]], former Security Minister and Speaker of Parliament. This displeased rival factions in ZANU-PF, and government investigations were started into the affairs of Bredenkamp's Breco trading company concerning tax evasion and exchange control violations. The matters under investigation were transactions between Breco in Zimbabwe and offshore companies controlled by Bredenkamp.
Bredenkamp has been linked to claims to facilitate the retirement of Mugabe in 2000, by the Guardian's investigation into the leaked US embassy cables<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/dec/18/tzvangirai-mdc-wikileaks-mugabe-zanu|title=WikiLeaks cables: UN offered Robert Mugabe a lucrative retirement overseas|last=Doward|first=Jamie|date=2010-12-18|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-06-25}}</ref>
In September 2006 Bredenkamp was tried in Zimbabwe on charges that he used a South African passport on international journeys. Zimbabwean citizenship law does not permit dual nationality. Although acquitted, he had to fight a second court case to obtain an order to return his Zimbabwe passport which the clerk of the court had retained. He was ordered to produce documentary evidence of his renunciation of South African citizenship to have his nationality restored permanently.<ref>The Herald, September 2006 :[http://allafrica.com/stories/200609240048.html court returns Bredenkamp’s passport]</ref> But his passport was returned.
In April 2016, ''[[The Guardian]]'' reported that Bredenkamp has an "estimated £700m fortune from tobacco trading, grey-market arms dealing, sports marketing and diamond mining."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2016/apr/06/mugabe-zimbabwe-john-bredenkamp-billy-rautenbach-offshore-sanctions-panama-papers|title=Alleged Mugabe cronies kept offshore firms years after UN alert raised|last=Garside|first=Juliette|last2=Pegg|first2=David|date=2016-04-06|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-06-25|last3=Watt|first3=Holly}}</ref>
Bredenkamp is the subject of US sanctions aimed at people of significant influence within the Zimbabwean government.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sanctionssearch.ofac.treas.gov/Details.aspx?id=2088|title=Sanctions List Search|website=sanctionssearch.ofac.treas.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-10-03}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox person |name = John Fredriksen |image = Stelios meeting1989.jpg |caption = Fredriksen (centre) and [[Stelios Haji-Ioannou]] (far left) at a meeting in 1989. |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1944|5|10}} |birth_place = [[Eidsvoll]], Norway |death_date = |death_place = |residence = London, England |nationality = [[Cyprus|Cypriot]] |other_names = |spouse = |known_for = Owner of [[Golden Ocean Group]]
Owner of [[Deep Sea Supply]]
Shareholder of [[Overseas Shipholding Group]] |net_worth = US$7.4 billion (April 2018){{cite news|title=John Fredriksen|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/john-fredriksen/|publisher=Forbes}} |alma_mater = |occupation = [[Business magnate]] |website = }} '''John Fredriksen''' (born 10 May 1944) is a Norwegian-born [[oil tanker]] and [[shipping]] [[Business magnate|magnate]], who owns the world's largest oil tanker fleet. He also has major interests in the [[offshore drilling|offshore driller]] [[Seadrill]], the [[fish farming]] company [[Marine Harvest]], the dry bulk company [[Golden Ocean Group]], and the [[Platform supply vessel|supply vessel]] company [[Deep Sea Supply]]. Through his investment companies [[Hemen Holdings]] and [[Meisha]], Fredriksen controls the companies [[Frontline Ltd|Frontline]] and [[Golar LNG]]. In 2010–2011, Frontline owned 9.6 percent of another large tanker company, [[Overseas Shipholding Group]].Bjørn Haugan, Johann D. Sundberg, [[Lars Magne Sunnanå]]: ''Flytter for døtrene'' (E24. 11 May 2006) [http://e24.no/boers-og-finans/article1312209.ece] North Atlantic Drilling, Sevan Drilling, and Asia Offshore Drilling are partly owned by Seadrill.{{cite web|url=http://seekingalpha.com/article/2852576-understanding-seadrills-complicated-financial-structure-the-asset-side?auth_param=10rf:1acen5e:5a48e21493fc93671a63d0154564ea50&uprof=45|title=Understanding Seadrill's Complicated Financial Structure: The Asset Side|first=Power|last=Hedge|date=27 January 2015|publisher=}} Born in [[Oslo]], Norway, Fredriksen is a [[Cypriot passport|Cypriot citizen]] who resides in London.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/mar/18/super-rich-made-cyprus-home|title=The super-rich who have made Cyprus their home|first=Simon|last=Bowers|date=18 March 2013|publisher=|via=www.theguardian.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/john-fredriksen-richest-man-in-cyprus-2013-3|title=The Richest Person In Cyprus Is Actually Norwegian|publisher=}} Before abandoning his Norwegian citizenship, he was Norway's richest man.De Lange, Grete. [http://www.aftenposten.no/english/business/article1314163.ece ''Norway's richest man no longer''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070808041748/http://www.aftenposten.no/english/business/article1314163.ece |date= 8 August 2007 }} (Aftenposten. 11 May 2006) Norwegian magazine ''[[Finansavisen|Kapital]]'' listed Fredriksen in 2013 with a net worth of [[Norwegian krone|NOK]] 69,75 billion ({{US$}}11.9 billion).{{cite web|title=Kapital 400|url=http://www.hegnar.no/bors/article705549.ece|accessdate=3 May 2013}} In 2012, he was included in the [[50 Most Influential (Bloomberg Markets ranking)|50 Most Influential]] list of [[Bloomberg Markets]] Magazine. He was named in the top 10 most influential people in the shipping industry according to Lloyds List 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.lloydslist.com/ll/news/top100/article452967.ece|title=10. John Fredriksen, Seatankers|date=12 December 2014|publisher=}} == Biography == === Family === Fredriksen was born on 10 May 1944 to a welder and his wife, and grew up in Etterstad in the eastern half of [[Oslo]]. Fredriksen is a widower and has two twin daughters: Cecilie and [[Kathrine Fredriksen|Kathrine Astrup Fredriksen]] (both born 1983). Fredriksen's former wife, dentist Inger Astrup Fredriksen (died 2006), originally belonged to one of the Astrup families in Norway. Her father was a professor of psychiatry, and her grand uncle was the painter [[Nikolai Astrup]]. === Business === Fredriksen made his fortune during the [[Iran–Iraq War]] in the 1980s, when his tankers picked up oil at great risk and huge profits. As described by his biographer, "he was the lifeline to the [[Ayatollah]]." Fredriksen would later become the world's largest tanker owner, with more than seventy oil tankers and major interests in oil rigs and fish farming. His fleet is dominated by costly double-hulled, environmentally safer tankers.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/christopherhelman/2012/03/21/how-shipping-king-john-fredriksen-found-a-port-in-the-storm/|title=How Shipping King John Fredriksen Found A Port In The Storm|first=Christopher|last=Helman|work=Forbes}} In 2006, Seadrill bought more than 50 percent of [[Smedvig]], gaining control of the company (51.24 percent of the votes and 52.27 percent of the capital). Smedvig is Fredriksen's biggest ever deal. Noble Corp sold its stake to Seadrill in 2009, leaving Seadrill with full control.Nina Berglund [http://www.aftenposten.no/english/business/article1266407.ece Smedvig now fully under Fredriksen's control] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629155723/http://www.aftenposten.no/english/business/article1266407.ece |date=29 June 2011}} ''Aftenposten''; 3 April 2006 Fredriksen has been the majority owner of [[Vålerenga Fotball|Vålerenga I.F.]] for many years.{{Citation needed|date=April 2015}} === Fortune === The ''[[Sunday Times Rich List]]'' has ranked Fredriksen's wealth as £475m (2003), £1.050b (2004) and £1.887b (2005). In 2012, Fredriksen and his family were listed as the 9th richest in Britain with a combined wealth of £6.6bn.{{cite news |title=Sunday Times Rich List shows UK's wealthiest defy recession|author=|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-17883101|newspaper=[[BBC News Online]]|date=28 April 2012|accessdate=28 April 2012}} Fredriksen owns houses in London, Oslo, Cyprus, and [[Marbella]], Spain. His house [[56 Old Church Street|The Old Rectory]] in London has been estimated to be worth around US$172 million.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/shipping-magnate-john-fredriksen-sticks-to-his-gut-feeling-invest/2012/09/21/0432903c-00dc-11e2-b260-32f4a8db9b7e_story.html|title=Shipping magnate John Fredriksen sticks to his ‘gut feeling’: Invest|first1=Edward|last1=Robinson|first2=Michelle Wiese|last2=Bockmann|date=22 September 2012|publisher=|accessdate=14 March 2018|via=www.washingtonpost.com}} He is a collector of classic Norwegian art.{{cite web|url=http://www.bornrich.com/john-fredriksen.html|title=John Fredriksen - Bornrich|date=29 May 2012|publisher=}} === Philanthropy === Fredriksen supports research projects at [[Norwegian Radium Hospital|Radium Hospital]]{{cite web|url=http://ous-research.no/dgo/|title=Dept. of Gyn. Oncology - Cancer Medicine - Divisions - Oslo University Hospital Research|website=ous-research.no}} and has donated several hundreds of millions of Norwegian kroner to medical research at hospitals in Norway.{{cite web|url=http://www.tradewindsnews.com/weekly/337168/messenger-boy-who-became-a-shipping-billionaire|title=Messenger boy who became a shipping billionaire|date=9 May 2014|publisher=}} === ''Gard'' case === In 1985, the Norwegian insurance company [[Assuranceforeningen Gard|Gard]] became suspicious about losses of cargo from Fredriksen's tankers. A private investigation was initiated, and a system for the use of heavy oil as bunker fuel was revealed.«For Oslo-advokatene ble Gisvolds reise slutten på den hemmelige etterforskningen. Man hadde nok, og dessuten var det nå bare et tidsspørsmål før Fredriksen fikk kjennskap til granskningen. Følgelig torde man ikke holde på lenger. Juristene anbefalte Gard å gå til politiet med sine mistanker.», fra Storeulv, side 106 The case was turned over to the Norwegian police and in June 1986 Fredriksen's offices in Oslo were searched and several of his nearest associates, and after a while also Fredriksen, were placed in detention while the case was investigated.«Samme morgen ble de seks arresterte fremstilt for Oslo forhørsrett. Siktelsen var grove oljetyverier og forsikringssvindel for cirka en million kroner.», fra Storeulv, side 125 After several years of arguments between the various lawyers, the case was settled out of court. Fredriksen had to pay a fine of 2 million NOK«John Fredriksen måtte i 1990 godta en bot på to millioner kroner for å ha satt mannskapenes liv i fare ved å bruke olje fra lasten som drivstoff.», fra Storeulv, side 168 for risking his crew's lives, and in addition had to pay the insurance company Gard an amount of over {{US$}}800,000.«Fredriksen aksepterte å betale Gard 800,000-dollar, pluss halvparten av den Marine Management-konto de hadde tatt beslag i.», fra Storeulv, side 160 == References == {{reflist|30em}} == Literature == * Hauge, Odd Harald and Gunnar Stavrum. ''Storeulv, en uautorisert biografi om John Fredriksen''. Oslo: Gyldendal, 2005. {{ISBN|978-82-05-35346-6}}. Print. == External links == *[http://www.lloydslist.com/ll/news/article413306.ece Lloyd's List 100 most Influential People in Shipping] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fredriksen, John}} [[Category:1944 births]] [[Category:Cypriot billionaires]] [[Category:Cypriot businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Norwegian billionaires]] [[Category:Norwegian businesspeople in shipping]] [[Category:Norwegian businesspeople]] [[Category:Norwegian emigrants to Cyprus]] [[Category:People from Oslo]] [[Category:Norwegian people of Danish descent]] [[Category:Cypriot people of Danish descent]]

revision.text:
'''Michael Bickford''' is an [[United States|American]] businessman. He is the founder of [[Round Hill Capital]], a real estate investment firm.
==Biography== ===Early life=== Michael Bickford was born in [[Greenwich, Connecticut]].<ref name="laindiana">[http://laindianapolo.com/concept/players/ La Indiana Polo Club: Management]</ref> His father, who was a [[polo]] player, owns a farm in [[Vermont]].<ref name="pololine">[http://www.pololine.com/?lang=1&sec=3&note=2639 Michael Bickford: Interview in St. Moritz], ''Polo Line'', February 10, 2013</ref> He graduated from [[Vanderbilt University]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].<ref name="roundhill">[http://roundhillcapital.com/our-team/uk/ Round Hill Capital: UK Team] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130918064836/http://roundhillcapital.com/our-team/uk/ |date=2013-09-18 }}</ref>
===Career=== Michael has over 18 years experience in private equity real estate. From 1995 to 2002, he worked as an acquisition professional for the [[Morgan Stanley]] Real Estate Funds.<ref name="roundhill"/> In 2002, he founded [[Round Hill Capital]], a real estate investment firm which has invested approximately $6 billion of capital in European real estate since its inception.<ref name="laindiana"/><ref name="roundhill"/><ref name="roundhillhistory">[http://roundhillcapital.com/about-us/history/ Round Hill Capital: History]</ref>
===Personal life=== Michael plays high goal polo competitively in England, Spain, France and the United States. He started playing polo at a young age with his father in Vermont and today plays against the top players in the world by competing in the Queens Cup, British Open, Gold Cup in Spain, and the high goal tournaments in Wellington, FL. La Indiana is the team name and is considered one of the most competitive teams in the world today. Michael was ranked the best polo Amateur in the world last year.

R. }}</ref><ref name=rayner3>{{Cite conference | doi = 10.1109/ICASSP.1989.266647| chapter = A new connectionist model based on a non-linear adaptive filter| title = International Conference on Acoustics, Speech, and Signal Processing| pages = 1191| year = 1989| last1 = Rayner | first1 = P. J. W. | last2 = Lynch | first2 = M. R. }}</ref> | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = [[Autonomy Corporation]] | influences = | influenced = | awards = {{Plainlist| * [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] * [[Royal Academy of Engineering|FREng]] (2008)<ref name=listoffellows>{{cite web|title=List of Fellows|url=http://www.raeng.org.uk/about-us/people-council-committees/the-fellowship/list-of-fellows}}</ref> * [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (2014)<ref name="royal">{{cite web|url=https://royalsociety.org/people/fellowship/2014/michael-lynch/|title=Dr Michael Lynch OBE FREng FRS|archivedate=2014-05-02|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140502071426/https://royalsociety.org/people/fellowship/2014/michael-lynch/}}</ref>}} | signature = <!--(filename only)--> | signature_alt = | website = <!-- {{URL|www.example.com}} --> | footnotes = | spouse = }}
'''Michael Richard Lynch''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR||OBE|DL|FRS|FREng}} (born 16 June 1965)<ref name="whoswho"/> is an entrepreneur with a scientific background. He is the co-founder of [[Autonomy Corporation]] and the founder of Invoke Capital, and has several other roles, including membership of the Council for Science and Technology which advises the UK government. His entrepreneurship is associated with [[Silicon Fen]]. Lynch is known for his work applying techniques from signal processing and pattern recognition to unstructured information, and Autonomy is a leader in this area. In October 2011, Autonomy was sold to [[Hewlett-Packard]] for $11bn.<ref name="Profile: Mike Lynch">[https://www.theguardian.com/business/2011/aug/19/profile-mike-lynch-autonomy Profile: Mike Lynch] The Guardian, 19 August 2011</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.director.co.uk/MAGAZINE/2011/5_May/mike-lynch_64_09.html|title=Good Listener|date=May 2011|work=Director magazine|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111025053845/http://director.co.uk/MAGAZINE/2011/5_May/mike-lynch_64_09.html|archivedate=25 October 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.salon.com/tech/view/2000/07/10/autonomy|title=Britain's first software billionaire|date=July 2000|work=[[salon.com]]}} (interview)</ref>
==Early life and education== Lynch was born in [[Ilford]], [[Essex]] in 1965 and grew up near [[Chelmsford, Essex]]. His mother was a nurse and his father a fireman.<ref name="business.timesonline.co.uk">[http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/movers_and_shakers/article4289418.ece Business big shot: Mike Lynch of Autonomy] The Times, 8 July 2008</ref>
In 1976, aged 11, he won a scholarship to [[Bancroft's School]], [[Woodford, London|Woodford]].<ref>[http://www.bancroftians.net/UserFiles/File/obaagmdocs.pdf OBA President's Report - 2009]</ref> From there he went to [[Christ's College, Cambridge]] to study [[Natural Sciences (Cambridge)|Natural Sciences]]. He combined mathematics, biological and physical sciences, taking the combination of advanced physics, mathematics and biochemistry in the IB [[Tripos]]. For part II, he chose electrical sciences where he first met Peter Rayner,<ref name="wired"/><ref name=rayner2/><ref name=rayner3/><ref name=raynerswho>{{Who's Who | surname = RAYNER| othernames = Prof. Peter John Wynn | id = U41852 | volume = 2015 | edition = online edition via [[Oxford University Press]]}} {{subscription required}}</ref> his mentor in the signal processing laboratory of the engineering department. After graduating he went on to do a [[PhD]] in [[signal processing]]<ref name="lynchphd">{{cite thesis |degree=DPhil |first=Michael Richard|last=Lynch |title=Adaptive techniques in signal processing and connectionist models |publisher=University of Cambridge |date=1990 |url=http://ulmss-newton.lib.cam.ac.uk/vwebv/holdingsInfo?bibId=11028|authorlink=Michael Richard Lynch}}</ref> and communications research at the [[University of Cambridge]], and then undertook a research fellowship in adaptive pattern recognition.<ref name="BBC Press Office">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2006/12_december/14/directors.shtml|title=BBC - Press Office - BBC appoints Executive Board|publisher=|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref>
==Entrepreneurial career== In the late 1980s Lynch formed Lynett Systems Ltd, producing designs and audio products for the music recording industry including the first ever sampler for the Atari ST, the Lynex, which was followed by the ADAS sampler for Atari, Mac & PC. This led to the offshoot D2D Systems which produced a software-only hard disk recording system for the Atari Falcon.
In 1991 he set up ''Cambridge Neurodynamics'', which specialized in computer-based finger print recognition.<ref>[http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/research/security/seminars/1995/95-11-14.html Security Group Seminar] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121202211844/http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/research/security/seminars/1995/95-11-14.html |date=2 December 2012 }} University of Cambridge</ref>
In 1996 Lynch co-founded [[Autonomy Corporation]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20060628201313/http://www.vnunet.com/networkitweek/features/2058993/kindness-strangers The Kindness of Strangers] VNU Net</ref> and he served Autonomy as CEO. During this time Autonomy acquired Dremedia, Virage ($13m), Verity ($500m), Zantaz ($375m) and Interwoven ($606m).<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/technology-media-telco-SP/idUSL0322638020070703 Autonomy to buy Zantaz for $375m, place shares] Reuters, 3 July 2007</ref>
In October 2011 Autonomy was sold to Hewlett-Packard for $11 billion.<ref name="Profile: Mike Lynch"/>
In May 2012, HP fired Mike Lynch.<ref>[http://www.pcr-online.biz/news/read/hp-fires-mike-lynch/028388 HP fires Mike Lynch] PCR, 25 May 2012</ref>
In February 2013, Lynch raised $1 billion through his Invoke Capital fund to invest in up and coming British technology companies.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/banksandfinance/9859582/Mike-Lynch-raises-1bn-for-technology-investment.html| title=Mike Lynch raises $1bn for technology investment | author=Ben Martin | publisher=Telegraph | date=9 February 2013}}</ref>
In September 2013, Lynch announced Invoke had made its first investment, putting up to $20m into [[Darktrace]] (alongside Hoxton Ventures and Talis Capital) which describes itself as "the world's first behavioural cyber defence platform."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/mediatechnologyandtelecoms/digital-media/10314823/British-tech-entrepreneur-Lynch-invests-in-cybersecurity-firm-backed-by-ex-MI5-boss.html|title=British tech entrepreneur Lynch invests in cybersecurity firm backed by ex-MI5 boss|date=17 September 2013|work=Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref><ref name="The Economist">{{cite web|url=https://www.economist.com/news/britain/21586555-technology-entrepreneurs-new-venture-makes-its-first-investment-after-autonomy|title=After Autonomy|work=The Economist|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref><ref name="dark_Dark">{{Cite web | title = Darktrace {{!}} Investors | author = | work = darktrace.com | date = | accessdate = 2016-05-24 | url = https://www.darktrace.com/investors/ | quote = }}</ref> In July 2015, Summit Partners invested a further $22.5 million in Darktrace, valuing the company at $120million.<ref name="The Guardian">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/jul/22/mike-lynch-darktrace-valued-at-more-than-60m-pounds|title=Mike Lynch's cybersecurity startup Darktrace valued at more than £60m|author=Juliette Garside|work=the Guardian|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref>
==Other interests==
He is a member of the board of Cambridge Enterprise,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.enterprise.cam.ac.uk/news/2010/9/one-britains-leading-entrepreneurs-joins-cambridge/|title=News Archive - Cambridge Enterprise|author=Your Name Here|work=Cambridge Enterprise|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref> and a member of the Council for Science and Technology.<ref>[http://www.number10.gov.uk/news/members-appointed-to-the-council-for-science-and-technology-2/ Members appointed to Council for Science & Technology] 10 Downing Street</ref> He is also a member of the Council of the Foundation for Science and Technology<ref>[http://www.foundation.org.uk/about/council/default.htm Foundation for Science and Technology] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20131011235551/http://www.foundation.org.uk/about/council/default.htm |date=11 October 2013 }}</ref> and a Hub Mentor in the Enterprise Hub of the Royal Academy of Engineering.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://enterprisehub.raeng.org.uk/mentors/|title=Enterprise Hub - Mentors|publisher=|accessdate=16 December 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222110407/http://enterprisehub.raeng.org.uk/mentors/|archivedate=22 December 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Lynch is a trustee of the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]],<ref>[http://www.kew.org/support-kew/about-kew-foundation/board-of-trustees/ Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140106040434/http://www.kew.org/support-kew/about-kew-foundation/board-of-trustees/ |date=6 January 2014 }}</ref> and a member of the board of the Create the Change Campaign at the Crick Institute, for Cancer Research UK.<ref>[http://support.cancerresearchuk.org/support-us/donate/become-a-major-donor/how-you-can-give/create-the-change/meet-the-team Meet the team] Cancer Research UK</ref>
He was a non executive director of Blinkx plc.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blinkx.com/corporate/investors/shareholder-information|title=Shareholder Information|publisher=Blinkx|accessdate=5 August 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140923103830/http://www.blinkx.com/corporate/investors/shareholder-information|archivedate=23 September 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
He has previously served as a non-executive director to the board of the [[BBC]],<ref name="BBC Press Office"/> on the board of the [[British Library]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bl.uk/aboutus/governance/blboard/memberslist/drmlynch/|title=Mike Lynch|publisher=British Library|accessdate=6 August 2014}}</ref> and as a trustee of the National Endowment for Science Technology and the Arts (NESTA), where he was chairman of their investment committee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wired-gov.net/wg/wg-news-1.nsf/0/3E8156AF783017E88025765E003CA045?OpenDocument|title=Mike Lynch|publisher=NESTA|accessdate=6 August 2014}}</ref>
==Awards, honours and media coverage== In September 2012 he was inducted into the Digital Hall of Fame, British Interactive Media Association.<ref>[http://www.digitalhalloffame.com/halloffamers Digital Hall of Fame] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130915011727/http://www.digitalhalloffame.com/halloffamers |date=15 September 2013 }}</ref>
He was named Entrepreneur of the Year in 1999 by the [[Confederation of British Industry]] and was awarded the [[Institution of Electrical Engineers]] medal for outstanding achievement.<ref>Institute of Engineering [http://www.theiet.org/about/scholarships-awards/achievement/recipients.cfm?type=pdf Recipients of the Achievement Awards] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090212134719/http://www.theiet.org/about/scholarships-awards/achievement/recipients.cfm?type=pdf |date=12 February 2009 }}</ref>
''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine named Lynch in their 25 most influential technology people in Europe in 2000.<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/europe/digital/2000/12/lynch.html "Mike Lynch - Autonomy"] Time Europe</ref>
The World Economic Forum presented Lynch with an award for Autonomy as a technology pioneer in 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.autonomy.com/content/News/Releases/2000/0201.en.html|title=Filter News Results - HP Newsroom Filter News Results|publisher=|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref> Lynch was awarded an [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] in the [[2006 New Year Honours]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/cambridgeshire/4569802.stm MBE for Soham murders detective] BBC News, 31 December 2005</ref>
He is a Lady Margaret Beaufort fellow of [[Christ's College, Cambridge]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christs.cam.ac.uk/college-life/people/fellows/lmb-fellows/|title=Lady Margaret Beaufort Fellows|publisher=|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref>
In 2007, he was awarded Technology Entrepreneur of the year by the European Technology Forum at their 2007 conference.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.innovationandgrowthforum.com/awards/previouswinners/|title=Innovation & Growth Forum|publisher=|accessdate=16 December 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090425001217/http://www.innovationandgrowthforum.com/awards/previouswinners/|archivedate=25 April 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In March 2008, he was chosen Innovator of the year at the European Business Leader of the year awards 'EBLA'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ebla2008.com|title=European Business Leaders Awards website|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080321185912/http://www.ebla2008.com/|archivedate=21 March 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In June 2008, he was elected a [[Fellow]]<ref name=listoffellows/> of the [[Royal Academy of Engineering]].<ref name=RAE>[http://www.raeng.org.uk/about/fellowship/pdf/newsletter/Spring_News_2009.pdf Royal Academy of Engineering]</ref>
In October 2008, Silicon.com readers voted him one of the top five most influential people in technology along with [[Tim Berners-Lee]], [[Steve Jobs]], [[Jimmy Wales]] and [[Eric Schmidt]].<ref>[http://www.silicon.com/research/specialreports/agenda-setters-2008/ "Agenda Setters 2008"]</ref> In January 2009, ''[[Management Today]]'' chose him as entrepreneur of the year.<ref name=RAE/>
Lynch has twice been a finalist for Investor Relations award of the year.<ref>[http://www.prnewswire.co.uk/cgi/news/release?id=201949 Barclays, Cookson and Detica Grand Prix Winners at IR Magazine Awards] PR Newswire, 29 June 2009</ref> In 2009 he was voted one of the top 25 best [[CEO]]s pan sector in Europe by fund managers in the annual Extel survey.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.docstoc.com/docs/7488204/Extel-Survey-European-Investor-Relations-2009|title=Docstoc is Closed|publisher=|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref> He is Deputy Lieutenant of the County of Suffolk.<ref>[http://www.suffolk.gov.uk/your-council/lieutenancy-and-honours/deputy-lieutenants-of-the-county-of-suffolk/ Deputy Lieutenants of the County of Suffolk] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140330060121/http://www.suffolk.gov.uk/your-council/lieutenancy-and-honours/deputy-lieutenants-of-the-county-of-suffolk/ |date=30 March 2014 }}</ref> In October 2013 he accompanied the Chancellor, George Osborne, on a trade mission to China.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/china-business/10373854/London-will-offer-China-more-than-Singapore-can-says-Boris-Johnson.html|title=London will offer China more than Singapore can, says Boris Johnson|date=12 October 2013|work=Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref>
His nomination for the [[Royal Society]] reads {{centered pull quote|Distinguished as a world leader in the application of non-linear adaptive signal processing and pattern recognition to unstructured information. Founder of Autonomy the UKs largest software company which was sold to HP for $11Bn in 2011. Creator of the Bayesian framework and platform at the heart of Autonomy's products and CEO of the company for 15 years. An inspiration and role model for entrepreneurs particularly in the engineering and technology sectors providing mentoring, enthusiasm, and financing at scale. An advisor to the government and major organisations at the most senior levels.<ref name="royal"/>}}
The ''[[Financial Times]]'' has described Lynch as "the doyen of European software".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/60404cda-26eb-11d9-9157-00000e2511c8.html#axzz1atIbaUah|title=Dicom snaps up Neurascript|work=Financial Times|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref> PC Advisor has called him "Britain's most successful technology entrepreneur".<ref name="pcadvisor.co.uk">[http://www.pcadvisor.co.uk/news/software/3298219/the-thoughts-of-autonomy-ceo-mike-lynch/ The Thoughts of Autonomy CEO Mike Lynch] PC Advisor</ref> In a profile in the ''[[Sunday Times]]'', it was suggested in passing that Lynch is the nearest thing Britain has to [[Bill Gates]].<ref>James Ashton [http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/technology/article5627459.ece "Autonomy is at the heart of a new data revolution"] ''Sunday Times'', 1 February 2009</ref><ref name="telegraph.co.uk">[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/industry/8710037/Profile-Mike-Lynch-Autonomy-founder.html Profile: Mike Lynch, Autonomy founder] The Telegraph, 16 October 2011</ref><ref>[http://realbusiness.co.uk/news/mike-lynch-sells-his-autonomy-to-hewlett-packard Mike Lynch sells his Autonomy to Hewlett-Packard] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111026045226/http://realbusiness.co.uk/news/mike-lynch-sells-his-autonomy-to-hewlett-packard |date=26 October 2011 }} Real Business</ref>
==Disputes== Larry Ellison, the CEO of [[Oracle Corporation|Oracle]], when dealing with Lynch and his colleagues said : "either Mr Lynch has a very poor memory or he is lying".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gizmodo.com.au/2011/09/larry-ellison-of-oracle-calls-autonomy-ceo-lying-liar/|title=Larry Ellison Of Oracle Calls Autonomy CEO Lying Liar|publisher=Gizmodo|date=30 September 2011| accessdate=8 August 2014}}</ref> However Lynch was proved right when [[Frank Quattrone]], Autonomy's advisor, confirmed the presentation at the center of the controversy had been his and not given by Lynch as Oracle had asserted.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2011/09/30/quattrone_says_autonomy_is_right|title=Quattrone blasts Ellison, says Autonomy is right|publisher=The Register|date=30 September 2011|accessdate=8 August 2014}}</ref>
{{see also|Hewlett-Packard#Takeover of Autonomy}} On 20 November 2012, Hewlett-Packard announced a writedown of assets following the Autonomy purchase due to "disclosure failures and outright misrepresentations at Autonomy", which occurred before the acquisition.<ref name= "Open letter from Mike Lynch to the shareholders of Hewlett-Packard">{{cite web|url=http://www.opnlttr.com/letter/open-letter-mike-lynch-shareholders-hewlett-packard|title=Open letter from Mike Lynch to the shareholders of Hewlett-Packard|work=Open Letter|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref> The total writedown amounted to $8.8bn of the purchase cost of more than $10bn. <ref name= "Financial Times 20th Nov 2012">{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/6d2dd40e-3311-11e2-aabc-00144feabdc0.html#axzz2ClrfUvAF|title=HP takes $8.8bn hit over Autonomy|work=Financial Times|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref> These irregularities have been contested.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/26/technology/mike-lynch-autonomys-founder-says-hes-baffled-by-hps-claims.html |title=Mike Lynch, Autonomy's Founder, Says He's Baffled by H.P.'s Claims - NYTimes.com |work= |accessdate=2012-11-26}}</ref> HP stated a major part of the issue was it was unaware that Autonomy sold hardware, and claimed that this was booked as software and hidden from the auditors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www8.hp.com/us/en/hp-news/press-release.html?id=1334263#.U5g0-5SwLwg/|title=HP News - HP Issues Statement Regarding Autonomy Impairment Charge|publisher=}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2012/11/20/h-p-takes-big-hit-on-accounting-improprieties-at-autonomy/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=0|title=Hewlett's Loss: A Folly Unfolds, by the Numbers|first=Quentin Hardy and Michael J. de la|last=Merced|publisher=}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-11-20/hewlett-packard-profit-forecast-8-8-billion-charge.html/|title=HP Plunges on $8.8 Billion Charge From Autonomy Writedown|first1=Aaron|last1=Ricadela|first2=Amy Thomson-|last2=2012-11-20T22:03:35Z|publisher=}}</ref> An FT investigation unearthed documents that show that HP was in fact aware of Autonomy's hardware sales. They were booked as hardware and were fully disclosed to Deloitte, the Autonomy auditors.<ref name="ft.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/4b0e6140-97d3-11e3-8dc3-00144feab7de.html#slide0/|title=HP/Autonomy investigation: Tangled web of hardware and resellers|work=Financial Times|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref>
Lynch wrote an open letter to HP's shareholders, accusing HP of misleading them over the matter.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://autonomyaccounts.org/open-letter-from-mike-lynch-to-the-shareholders-of-hewlett-packard-2/|title=Open letter from Mike Lynch to the shareholders of Hewlett-Packard|publisher=|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref> Deloitte have also gone on the record supporting Lynch's opinion.<ref name="ft.com"/> Lynch and other ex-Autonomy executives have set up AutonomyAccounts.org to provide a platform to voice their rebuttal of criticism.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://autonomyaccounts.org/ | title=AutonomyAccounts.org|accessdate=2014-02-22}}</ref>
In August 2014, HP did a deal with law firms suing them on behalf of shareholders over the matter. HP would pay them and they would help HP sue Lynch and the former Autonomy CFO for [[fraud]]. HP's deal was objected to by a number of parties and was considered highly suspect as the lawyers were to be paid but not the shareholders. Judge Breyer threw the case out.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2014/07/03/dealpolitik-more-evidence-of-broken-shareholder-litigation-system|title=Dealpolitik: More Evidence of Broken Shareholder Litigation System|accessdate=5 August 2014}}</ref> HP's claims were investigated at HP's request by the [[Serious Fraud Office (United Kingdom)|UK Serious Fraud Office]], however the SFO announced in January 2015 that it was ending its investigation with no action.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-30883288|title=Autonomy HP sale investigation by Serious Fraud Office closes|date=19 January 2015|publisher=BBC|accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref>
On 29 November 2018 he was indicted for fraud in relation to the 2011 deal with HP.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-11-29/ex-autonomy-ceo-lynch-indicted-for-fraud-tied-to-2011-hp-deal?utm_source=google&utm_medium=bd&cmpId=google|title=Ex-Autonomy CEO Michael Lynch Indicted for Fraud Tied to 2011 HP Deal|publisher=Bloomberg|date=29 November 2018|accessdate=30 November 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life== He is married and has two daughters.<ref>[http://autonomyaccounts.org/biography/ Biography] AutonomyAccounts.org</ref> His entry in [[Who's Who (UK)]] lists his recreations as Jazz saxophone and preserving rare breeds.<ref name=whoswho/>

{{about|the street in San Francisco}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2012}} [[Image:Montgomery Street from Telegraph Hill, San Francisco.jpg|thumb|225px|Looking south down Montgomery Street from Telegraph Hill through the Financial District]]
'''Montgomery Street''' is a north-south thoroughfare in [[San Francisco]], [[California]], in the United States.
It runs about 16 blocks from the [[Telegraph Hill, San Francisco|Telegraph Hill]] neighborhood south through downtown, terminating at [[Market Street (San Francisco)|Market Street]]. South of [[Columbus Avenue (San Francisco)|Columbus Avenue]], Montgomery Street runs through the heart of San Francisco's [[Financial District, San Francisco|Financial District]] and contains one of the highest concentrations of financial activity, investment business, and venture capital in the [[United States]] and the world. For this reason, it is known as "the [[Wall Street of the West]]".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.streetcar.org/f-line.html|title=F-Market & Wharves Streetcar Line – Market Street Railway|accessdate=July 31, 2010}}</ref><ref name="GSA">{{cite book|last=Prentice|first=Carol S.|title=1906 San Francisco earthquake centennial field guides|year=2006|publisher=Geological Society of America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CwchZE54dWYC&pg=PA17 |accessdate=July 31, 2010|page=17|chapter=Walk 3:Montgomery Street to Jackson Square}}</ref> South of Market Street, the street continues as [[New Montgomery Street]] for two more blocks to terminate at Howard Street in the [[South of Market, San Francisco, California|SOMA]] district.
==History== [[Image:Montgomerystreetsf.jpg|thumb|225px|Looking north from Market Street up Montgomery Street towards the [[Transamerica Pyramid]]. In the foreground is the flagship branch of [[Wells Fargo Bank]].]]
In the 1830s, the land which is now Montgomery Street lay at the edge of [[San Francisco Bay]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sfmuseum.org/hist1/early.html|title=San Francisco – Before the Gold Rush – 1847|accessdate=July 31, 2010}}</ref><ref name=OHP>{{Cite web|url=http://ohp.parks.ca.gov/default.asp?page_id=21482|title=Office of Historic Preservation: San Francisco|accessdate=July 31, 2010}}</ref> Intense [[land speculation]] during the [[California Gold Rush|Gold Rush]] created a demand for more usable land in the rapidly growing city, and sandy bluffs near the waterfront were leveled and the shallows filled with sand (and the ruins of many ships) to make new building lots. Between 1849 and 1852, the waterfront advanced about four blocks.<ref>[[:File:1853 U.S.C.S. Map of San Francisco, California ^ Vicinity - Geographicus - SanFrancisco3-uscs-1853.jpg|City of San Francisco and its Vicinity California (Map, 1853)]]</ref> At present, Montgomery Street is about seven blocks from the water.
The corner of Montgomery and Clay is where [[John B. Montgomery]] landed when he came to hoist the [[Flag of the United States|U.S. flag]] after the [[Bear Flag Revolt]] of 1846. In 1853 the [[Montgomery Block]], a center of early San Francisco law and literature, was built at 600 Montgomery, on land currently occupied by the [[Transamerica Pyramid]].<ref name=OHP />
==Offices== [[Image:Historic American Buildings Survey A. J. Wittlock, Photographer March 1940 TELEGRAPH HILL AND MONTGOMERY STREET HOUSES - Telegraph Hill (House), 1301 Montgomery Street, San HABS CAL,38-SANFRA,126-1.tif|thumb|Montgomery Street building, 1940]] Many banks and financial-services companies have had offices in the buildings on or near Montgomery Street, especially between Market Street and Sacramento Street: * The world headquarters of [[Wells Fargo]] are at 420 Montgomery.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://yahoo.brand.edgar-online.com/displayfilinginfo.aspx?FilingID=7376060-1063-6229&type=sect&dcn=0001193125-10-167482|accessdate=July 31, 2010|title=EDGAR Online: Wells Fargo & Co/MN (WFC) – 8-K – 7/27/2010}}</ref> * [[555 California Street]], between [[Kearny Street|Kearny]] and Montgomery, served as [[Bank of America]]'s world headquarters prior to its merger with [[NationsBank]] and was (from 1969 to 2005) officially called the Bank of America Building.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.emporis.com/application/?nav=building&lng=3&id=118721|title=555 California St., San Francisco, CA|accessdate=July 31, 2010}}</ref> * The [[Transamerica Pyramid]] (600 Montgomery, at Columbus Avenue) was the headquarters of [[Transamerica Corporation]] and still appears in the company's logo.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.emporis.com/application/?nav=building&lng=3&id=118715|title=Transamerica Pyramid|accessdate=July 31, 2010}}</ref> * [[Melvin Belli]], lawyer known as "The King of Torts", had his offices at the ''Belli Building'' at 722-724 Montgomery St.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.coastnews.com/sf/belli.htm|title= When Renovation Meets Litigation -- And the Trash Piles Up|author= Crovo, Lisa|date= |work= |publisher= San Francisco Coastnews|accessdate= 12 September 2013}}</ref> Belli used to raise a [[Jolly Roger]] and fire a cannon every time he won a case.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.sfweekly.com/2000-04-12/news/battle-belli/|title= Battle Belli|author= Davis, Lisa|date= 12 April 2000|work= |publisher= [[San Francisco Weekly]]|accessdate= 12 September 2013}}</ref> * [[Bank of the West]] is headquartered at [[180 Montgomery Street]].
==High-rises== Notable high-rises and skyscrapers along Montgomery Street in the Financial District:
*[[44 Montgomery]] *[[Hunter-Dulin Building]] (111 Sutter at Montgomery) *[[100 Montgomery Street]] *[[101 Montgomery]] *[[180 Montgomery Street]] *[[Russ Building]] (235 Montgomery) *[[Commercial Union Assurance Building]] (315 Montgomery) *[[456 Montgomery Plaza]] *[[505 Montgomery Street]] *[[Transamerica Pyramid]] (600 Montgomery) A building bearing the name of [[One Montgomery Tower]] is located at the intersection of [[Post Street|Post]] and [[Kearny Street|Kearny]] streets, behind the Wells Fargo flagship branch and [[Crocker Galleria]].
==Public transit== Montgomery Street is served by the [[Bay Area Rapid Transit|BART]] and [[Muni Metro]] [[Montgomery Street Station]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bart.gov/stations/mont/index.aspx|accessdate=July 31, 2010|title=BART – Montgomery St.}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox video game | title = Mugsy | developer = Philip Mitchell
Clive Barrett
Russell Comte | publisher = [[Krome Studios Melbourne|Melbourne House]] | designer = | released = [[1984 in video gaming|1984]] | genre = [[Strategy and Management]] | modes = [[Single player]] | platforms = [[ZX Spectrum]]}} '''''Mugsy''''' is a strategy and management [[computer game]] for the 48K [[ZX Spectrum]]. It was well-received, mainly due to its innovative graphic style, and was followed two years later by a sequel. == Gameplay == The player takes the role of "Mugsy", an American [[gangster]]. The aim of the game is for Mugsy to become "the most powerful gang leader in the city".{{cite web|url=http://www.worldofspectrum.org/pub/sinclair/games-info/m/Mugsy.txt|accessdate=26 June 2015|publisher=World of Spectrum|title=Instructions}} In each 'turn' of the game, which represents one year, decisions must be made about how much money should be spent on weapons and ammunition to fight other gangs, how many business from which he should attempt to extract [[protection money]], and how much bribery of local law enforcement should take place. The game was marketed as a "interactive video comic strip";{{cite web|url=http://www.worldofspectrum.org/pub/sinclair/games-adverts/m/Mugsy.jpg|accessdate=26 June 2015|publisher=Melbourne House|title=Mugsy Advertisement}} it was highly visual, with graphics (produced using the software house's own title, [[Melbourne Draw]]) intended to be similar to [[comic book]] drawings. Information was presented to the player in the form of dialogue between on-screen characters, such as Mugsy himself, and an unnamed assistant. At each decision point, the player enters text into a 'speech bubble' dialogue box. There was no real plot or narrative arc within the game as a whole; each year's activities were essentially the same, with the same decisions being required to be made by the player. However, there was a small [[Action game|arcade]] element, which was triggered in the event that one of Mugsy's rivals orders a [[contract killing]] on him. When this happened, the player controls Mugsy directly, and must shoot the assassins who are sent after him before he being shot too many times himself. ==Release== The title was heavily publicised in the year of its release, with at least 26 advertisements in the trade press, many of them 2-page spreads.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldofspectrum.org/infoseekid.cgi?id=0006715|title=Mugsy - World of Spectrum|publisher=|accessdate=27 June 2015}} The release of the game was preceded by a promotional campaign including actors dressed as gangsters visiting the offices of some computing magazines.{{cite web|url=http://www.crashonline.org.uk/06/news.htm|title=CRASH 6 - News|publisher=|accessdate=27 June 2015}} It was originally released in 1984 in the UK, by [[Krome Studios Melbourne|Melbourne House]]. It was later re-released in Spain by Iveson Software SA. It was priced at £6.95 in the UK, and 1900 [[Spanish peseta|pesetas]] for the Spanish re-released version.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldofspectrum.org/infoseekid.cgi?id=0006715|title=Mugsy - World of Spectrum|accessdate=27 June 2015}} In 1986, it was included in a compilation of titles called 'Off The Hook', aimed at raising money to combat drug addiction.{{cite web|url=http://www.ysrnry.co.uk/articles/tzers0586.htm|title=T'zers|publisher=|accessdate=27 June 2015|author=Maughan, Teresa}} == Reception == Reviews of the Spectrum edition were very positive; ''[[Your Sinclair]]'''s "Joystick Jury" rated it a "hit", citing its impressive graphics, and a structure that, while logical, provided a high level of replayability, as each game ended differently.{{cite web|url=http://www.users.globalnet.co.uk/~jg27paw4/yr08/yr08_59.htm|title=Your Spectrum 08 - Joystick Jury|publisher=|accessdate=27 June 2015}} It was also the winner of a ''[[Crash (magazine)| Crash]]'' Reader's Award for "Best Strategy and Simulation". The magazine commented positively on the graphics, partly because the visual style was "suited to a game set in the roaring twenties";{{cite web|url=http://www.crashonline.org.uk/12/awards.htm|title=CRASH 12 - Readers' Awards|publisher=|accessdate=27 June 2015}} this was despite "Mugsy" having to take place before 1919, since that is when its sequel, ''[[Mugsy's Revenge]]'', begins. ==Legacy== A sequel, ''[[Mugsy's Revenge]]'' was published two years later, and ported to the [[Commodore 64]] and [[Amstrad CPC]]. Russel Comte, a leading member of the design team, went on to work as an artist on a number of other significant computer game titles.{{cite web|url=http://www.mobygames.com/developer/sheet/view/developerId,808/|title=Russel Comte Video Game Credits and Biography - MobyGames|work=MobyGames|accessdate=27 June 2015}} == References == {{reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mugsy's Revenge (Video Game)}} [[Category:1984 video games]] [[Category:Business simulation games]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:ZX Spectrum games]] [[Category:ZX Spectrum-only games]]

{{unreferenced|date=February 2011}} {{Infobox Organization |name = National Market Traders' Federation |image = |size = |caption = |abbreviation = NMTF |formation = 1899 |status = [[Non-profit organization|Non-profit company]] |purpose = To represents its members - about 30,000 retail market traders in the UK - at local, national and international government level, as well as providing them with the necessary liabilities insurance as part of membership |location = Hampton House, Hawshaw Lane (B6096), [[Hoyland]], [[Barnsley]], [[United Kingdom|UK]] |region_served = UK |membership = Retail market traders, street traders, events retailers and mobile caterers |leader_title = Chief Executive Officer |leader_name = Joe Harrison |leader_title2= Communications Manager, Deputy Chief Executive, Editor Market Times |leader_name2= Roy Holland |main_organ = Executive Board |parent_organization = |affiliations = Association of Town and City Centre Management World Union of Wholesale Markets Association of Festival Organisers |budget = |website = [http://www.nmtf.co.uk NMTF] }}
The '''National Market Traders' Federation''' is an organisation based in the borough of [[Barnsley]], [[South Yorkshire]].
==History== It was founded in 1899 by a group of Yorkshire West Riding market traders to represent their interests on a broader level. There are around 1,400 markets in the UK.
==Function== It maintains a database of all markets in the UK, including number of stalls and who to contact. It also offers insurance deals for market traders. It has negotiated deals with large companies, such as the [[The Automobile Association|AA]], for favourable rates for market traders. Single membership from 21 July 2012 is £102.
==External links== * [http://www.nmtf.co.uk National Market Traders Federation] * [http://www.howgreenisyourmarket.com How Green Is Your Market]
===Video clips=== * [https://www.youtube.com/user/fednews NMTF YouTube channel]
